title: Risk Management & Psychology
description: Master risk assessment, behavioral finance, avoiding common psychological traps, and building disciplined investment approach.
objectives: Understand different types of investment risks
Learn behavioral biases that affect investment decisions
Master risk measurement and management techniques
Develop emotional discipline and avoid common mistakes

lessons.title: Types of Investment Risk
lessons.videoTopic: Understanding Market, Credit, Liquidity, and Other Risks

content.original: Investment risks: (1) Market risk (systematic) - affects all securities, cannot be diversified away. (2) Company-specific risk (unsystematic) - affects individual stock, diversifiable. (3) Liquidity risk - difficulty selling without loss. (4) Credit risk - borrower default. (5) Interest rate risk - bond prices fall when rates rise. (6) Inflation risk - purchasing power erosion. (7) Currency risk - forex fluctuations. (8) Political/Regulatory risk - government policy changes. Understand risk-return tradeoff: Higher return requires accepting higher risk. Risk cannot be eliminated, only managed.
content.simplified: Different risks you face: (1) Market risk: Entire market falls, all stocks drop (2008, 2020). Can't avoid by diversification. (2) Company risk: One company's problems (fraud, bad management). Can avoid by owning many stocks. (3) Liquidity risk: Can't sell stock quickly without big loss (penny stocks). (4) Inflation risk: Your money's buying power decreases - â‚¹100 today worth â‚¹70 in 10 years. (5) Interest rate risk: When RBI increases rates, bond values fall. Key rule: Want higher returns? Must accept higher risk. No high return without risk - anyone promising that is lying.

lessons.aiSummary: Risk types: Market (systematic, non-diversifiable), Company-specific (unsystematic, diversifiable), Liquidity, Credit, Interest rate, Inflation, Currency, Political. Risk-return tradeoff fundamental. Can't eliminate risk, only manage it.
keyTakeaways: Market risk affects all stocks - bear markets are inevitable
Diversification eliminates company-specific risk only
Inflation is silent wealth destroyer (3-4% annually in India)
Risk tolerance must match investment choices
commonMistakes: Thinking diversification eliminates all risk (only unsystematic risk)
Ignoring inflation risk in fixed deposits (real returns often negative)
Taking on risk without understanding it (derivatives, penny stocks)
Confusing volatility with risk (short-term swings vs permanent loss)

lessons.title: Behavioral Finance & Biases

content.original: Behavioral biases affecting investors: (1) Loss aversion - pain of loss 2x pleasure of gain, leads to holding losers too long. (2) Confirmation bias - seeking information supporting existing belief, ignoring contradicting data. (3) Recency bias - overweighting recent events (bull market makes you overconfident). (4) Anchoring - fixating on arbitrary reference point (purchase price). (5) Herd mentality - following crowd without analysis. (6) Overconfidence - overestimating abilities. (7) Mental accounting - treating money differently based on source/use. Awareness is first step to overcoming biases. Follow systematic process, not emotions.
content.simplified: Psychological mistakes investors make: (1) Loss aversion: Losing â‚¹100 hurts more than gaining â‚¹100 feels good. Result: You hold losing stocks hoping they'll recover. (2) Confirmation bias: Stock you own - you only read positive news, ignore red flags. (3) Recency bias: Market goes up 6 months, you think it'll always go up. Then you invest at top. (4) Anchoring: Bought at â‚¹100, now â‚¹60. You wait for â‚¹100 even if company fundamentals changed. (5) Herd mentality: Everyone buying crypto, you buy too without research. (6) Overconfidence: 3 stocks go up, you think you're Warren Buffett. Solution: Follow written rules, not gut feelings.

lessons.aiSummary: Behavioral biases: Loss aversion (hold losers), Confirmation bias (selective data), Recency bias (extrapolate recent), Anchoring (fixate on price), Herd mentality (follow crowd), Overconfidence (overestimate skill). Awareness + systematic process overcome biases.
keyTakeaways: Emotions are biggest enemy in investing
Having written Investment Policy Statement prevents emotional decisions
Best investors are disciplined, not necessarily smartest
Market exploits psychological weaknesses systematically
commonMistakes: Selling winners too early, holding losers too long (opposite of correct)
Panic selling at market bottom (recency bias + herd mentality)
Overtrading after few successful trades (overconfidence)
Not having decision-making framework (fully emotional)

lessons.title: Risk Measurement & Assessment
lessons.videoTopic: Standard Deviation, Beta, Sharpe Ratio, VaR

content.original: Risk metrics: (1) Standard deviation - measures volatility of returns. Higher SD = more volatile. (2) Beta - measures stock's volatility relative to market. Beta >1 more volatile than market, <1 less volatile. (3) Sharpe ratio - risk-adjusted return. (Return - Risk-free rate) / SD. Higher is better. >1 is good, >2 is excellent. (4) Maximum drawdown - largest peak-to-trough decline. Important for psychological tolerance. (5) Value at Risk (VaR) - maximum expected loss at confidence level. Use these to compare investments and assess portfolio risk.
content.simplified: How to measure risk: (1) Standard deviation: How much returns jump around. If average return is 12% but some years -20% and some +40%, high SD (risky). FD has low SD (always 6-7%). (2) Beta: Compares stock to market. Beta 1.5 means if market moves 10%, stock moves 15%. High beta = high risk, high potential return. (3) Sharpe ratio: Which investment gives best return for risk taken? Compares two funds - higher Sharpe ratio is better. (4) Maximum drawdown: Biggest fall from peak. Can you handle 50% drop mentally? Most can't - choose investments matching your psychology.

keyTakeaways: Volatility (SD) and risk are related but not identical
Beta helps understand how stock moves with market
Sharpe ratio best for comparing funds/strategies
Know your maximum drawdown tolerance (30%? 50%?)
commonMistakes: Equating volatility with risk (short-term swings vs permanent loss)
Ignoring maximum drawdown (can you psychologically handle it?)
Not understanding beta (high beta stocks in bull, low in bear)
Choosing investments exceeding risk tolerance (leads to panic selling)

lessons.title: Building Investment Discipline

content.original: Discipline fundamentals: (1) Have written plan (IPS) and follow it. (2) Invest regularly regardless of market conditions (SIP discipline). (3) Avoid checking portfolio daily - reduces emotional decisions. (4) Set review schedule (quarterly/annually), not continuous monitoring. (5) Use checklists for buy/sell decisions. (6) Maintain investment journal - record reason for each trade, review quarterly. (7) Separate speculation money from investment money. (8) Never invest borrowed money or emergency fund. (9) Accept that losses are part of process. (10) Focus on process, not outcomes (good process leads to good outcomes over time).
content.simplified: How to build discipline: (1) Write your investing rules when calm, follow when market is crazy. (2) Start SIP and don't stop even if market falls (that's when you buy cheap). (3) Stop checking portfolio every day - makes you emotional and leads to bad decisions. Check monthly or quarterly. (4) Before buying stock, write down WHY. If it falls, read your reason - is it still valid? (5) Keep separate buckets: 80% serious long-term investing, 20% for trying new things/learning. Never mix. (6) Emergency fund separate - never invest money you might need in 2-3 years. (7) Remember: Even best investors are wrong 40% of time. It's normal.

lessons.aiSummary: Investment discipline: Written plan (IPS), Regular investing (SIP), Reduce monitoring frequency, Scheduled reviews, Decision checklists, Investment journal, Separate speculation from investment, No borrowed money, Accept losses, Process over outcomes.
keyTakeaways: Discipline beats intelligence in investing
Daily portfolio checking increases bad decisions by 3-4x
Investment journal helps learn from mistakes
Best time to invest is when you're most scared
commonMistakes: No written plan (all reactive decisions)
Checking portfolio multiple times daily (anxiety and overtrading)
Not maintaining investment journal (repeating same mistakes)
Stopping SIP during market falls (opposite of what should do)

lessons.title: Common Investor Mistakes to Avoid

content.original: Top investor mistakes: (1) Trying to time market - studies show 90% fail. Time IN market beats timing market. (2) Chasing past performance - last year's winner often this year's loser. (3) Overtrading - each trade has costs and taxes. (4) Ignoring taxes - STCG vs LTCG makes huge difference. (5) Not diversifying - concentration can destroy wealth quickly. (6) Following tips without research - "hot tips" usually arrive after move is over. (7) Investing without emergency fund - forced to sell investments at loss. (8) Lifestyle inflation eating returns - earning more but saving less. (9) Not starting early - compound interest needs time. (10) Expecting quick riches - wealth building takes years, shortcuts lead to losses.
content.simplified: Biggest mistakes to avoid: (1) Trying to predict tops and bottoms - impossible consistently. Better: Invest regularly through SIP. (2) Buying last year's top fund - it often underperforms next year. (3) Trading too much - every trade = brokerage + tax. Less is more. (4) Selling winners in 6 months (20% tax) instead of holding 1+ year (12.5% tax). Plan taxes. (5) Putting all money in one or two stocks - if they fail, you're finished. (6) Acting on WhatsApp tips - by time tip reaches you, smart money has already exited. (7) Starting to invest at 35 instead of 25 - you lose 10 years of compounding (massive difference). (8) Wanting to double money in 6 months - greed leads to scams and losses. Be patient.

keyTakeaways: Time in market > Timing market (data-proven)
Starting 10 years early can mean 5-10x more wealth (compounding)
Most 'tips' are manipulation or arrive too late
Slow and steady beats get-rich-quick every time
commonMistakes: Waiting for 'right time' to start investing (time never perfect)
Selling good stocks in panic during corrections
Following friends/relatives investment advice without research
Lifestyle inflation (spending all raises instead of investing)
